metadata.title: The Mathematics behind the Lock-down of a Country | by Chinmoy Rajurkar | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: The Mathematics behind the Lock-down of a Country
metadata.description: Disclaimer: The following piece of writing is not meant to cause panic, or hurt sentiments. There is no political judgement being handed out in this article. This is purely an opinion piece. I…

outgoing_paragraph_urls.anchor_text: India recently faced the largest migrant crisis in the wake of the lock-down when close to a million migrants in the larger cities of this nation decided to seek their way home.
Both these institutes are guiding the United Kingdom’s strategy towards this global crisis.
A recent study by the Institute of Mathematical Sciences
concluded that the effects of flattening began showing on the 6th of April.
The period of infection and R₀ is within bounds of what has been reported
A prominent economist has also identified with these findings, albeit with a different approach, and this has been presented to the Government of India as of the 24th of April.
India has been criticized for not conducting enough tests

all_paragraphs: Disclaimer: The following piece of writing is not meant to cause panic, or hurt sentiments. There is no political judgement being handed out in this article. This is purely an opinion piece. I possess expertise in neither mathematical modeling nor epidemiology. The findings made in this study are backed by logic and reasoning and have gone through due processes of review.
April 14th, New Delhi: As the clock struck 10:00, the Indian Prime Minister, Narendra Modi, made headlines when he addressed the nation of India after 21 days of feverish lock-down.
On the other side were 1.3 billion people, listening to his words with bated breath.

This was the all-crucial announcement. This would decide the terms, on which this country would function, for the next few months. A country where the number of cases from the n-CoV-SARS-2, known otherwise as the CoViD-19, outbreak was just over 10,000¹ cases.

The country was to remain under lock-down until the 3rd of May. While the objective realist in me breathed a sigh of relief at this closely averted disaster, the human in me could only feel the increasing frustration and despair.
By 10:45 am, the calls had begun to come in.

My mother called first.She’s marooned in Kochi, a city in the southern state of Kerala. It has been almost 4 months since I last saw her, and we all now realize that it is going to be a little while longer before we see each other again.

Then my little brother called. He’s with our grandparents, having moved out of his university just in time before the lock-down was declared. They’re all in New Delhi, the capital and one of the more adversely affected regions in this outbreak. He says he’s okay, but I can sense his apprehension. Or is it my own?
My family takes life as they see it. They are realists. Neither pessimists, nor optimists. We had all realized that this shutdown is necessary. Vital.
We’re not the only ones, scattered and disjoint, in this country.
India recently faced the largest migrant crisis in the wake of the lock-down when close to a million migrants in the larger cities of this nation decided to seek their way home.
We all long for home. Not the physical space, but everything else associated with it: stability, love, peace.
But, does anyone know if the lock-down worked at all?We don’t know that. I don’t know that.
In my previous post, Keep Your Distance Please, I had tried to illustrate why, and how, social distancing works through some complicated math, and hopefully some fairly intuitive concepts.
I was taken aback, and humbled, by the overwhelming response I got for that piece of writing. Thank you for the support, especially my reviewers who prefer to remain anonymous.

In this piece, I try and put forth my thoughts on whether such an extreme measure such as a lock-down works at all. It’s easy to opine, but far more difficult to support an opinion with empirical evidence. In this piece, we try and look for this supporting proof.
But before proceeding, I must caution the reader that we’ll be trying to establish this with a mathematical model. A margin of error is expected.
We try and fit this model onto the data for India. There have been concerns with the amount of testing carried out in this country, and that is a caveat we must be cognizant of.
The priors of any probabilistic model are often a matter of debate, and I’m open to hear alternate views on my choice.
We use the same model that was covered in the previous post, Keep Your Distance Please. An SIR model.
As a refresher, the SIR model²— first developed in 1927, is a set of differential equations, that try and segment a population into the Susceptible, Infective, and Removed groups.
By fitting the model to data, estimates for the parameters β and γ can be obtained.
β, γ are the two most important elements in this model.
The reason I choose an SIR approach, as compared to a more sophisticated model, is to limit the number of assumptions the system ends up making.
How do we solve for these parameters? Well, there are two prominent ways.
What we attempted in my previous post was a deterministic model— a model that results in a single solution.
Probabilistic models, on the other hand, can prove to be a paradigm shift. They are typically solved using simulations.
What are the differences between the two approaches?
A deterministic model does not include elements of randomness. Every time you run the model with the same initial conditions you will get the same results.
Most simple mathematical models of everyday situations are deterministic. The voltage running through your lamps? Deterministic.The interest that is earned through banking accounts? Deterministic.

A probabilistic model includes elements of randomness. Every time you run the model, you are likely to get slightly different results, even with the same initial conditions. These models incorporate some aspect of random variation.
The most intuitive explanation for the probabilistic approach is analogous to navigating with a map.

Suppose, you’re in a city you’ve never been to before, and you have to identify where you are. All you have is a map. Just when you’re losing all hope, your friend calls to tell you that you’re in the southern part of the city. This information is called the prior.
How are you going to locate yourself? Well, you look around.
You guess distances to the landmarks around you. These are what we call observations.
Logically, all you need to do is to identify these observations on the map given to you, and voila — you have found yourself.
But it’s not that simple for a machine. So, how can a machine do it?
To do this, we use MCMC sampling or Markov Chain Monte Carlo sampling. We pick points from the prior randomly, i.e., random points in the southern section of the city.
Using Bayes theorem, the result that everyone must’ve studied in their high school, the MCMC approach calculates chances of the following form for each and every point sampled…
“Given that I see this landmark at say, 200 meters, what’s the likelihood I am at this location?”

This is where MCMC shines. It searches intelligently. It aims to converge (hopefully) towards the areas of higher probability, by exploring nearby positions and continuously sampling from those areas. So over time, you are able to identify your location. This is a distribution — and, hence, you can understand the variation in the estimates that otherwise would’ve been reduced to a single point.
The earlier section looked at stating problems in Bayesian terms. For modeling CoViD-19, the probabilistic approach asks questions of the following form, for each and every day of observation,
“Given that we’ve observed 8,000 cases on day 19, what are the chances this happened with a R₀ of 2?”

In fact, probabilistic approaches to epidemic modeling have been used extensively in predicting the spread of CoViD-19 — the most notable uses being the work done at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine³, and the Imperial College of London⁴. Both these institutes are guiding the United Kingdom’s strategy towards this global crisis.

We use requests and pandas, two python libraries, to access the CoViD cases in India from here. They provide APIs, and a simple python script can extract the data. This is a crowd-sourced database, and the data has been in-line with other news reports.
To investigate the impact of the lock-down, we set change-points. What does that mean? A simple sketch explains the idea.
We are essentially saying that there are two points in time when the R₀ changes.
Here, the points τ₁, τ₂ are discrete in nature, and unknown. The process will attempt to estimate these. In each of these time periods, the R₀ is also unknown.
We first modify the differential equations to account for this
We state the model in pymc3 — a python package for probabilistic programming.
In the model definition above, we assume that all the R₀’s come from uniform distributions ranging from 1 to 6.
This means that every number between 1 and 6 has an equal probability of occurrence
The period of infection, 1/γ, otherwise defined as D∞, comes from a uniform distribution ranging from 0 days to 15 days.
This means that every number between 0 and 15 has an equal probability of occurrence
We assume that the period of infection for this virus will not change across the time periods. Only the contact rate changes.
The switch-points are set as discrete uniform priors — meaning they can only take discrete values ranging from 1 to the last day of the data, each day with an equal probability.
With these priors, we can fit the model using the Poisson distribution, as the data we’re dealing with is the raw count data.
Considering we’re working with close to 50 days of data, I’ve isolated the most recent 10% of data for validation. We run 6,000 simulations to estimate the parameters.
How does the model fit look like?
This results with a MAPE (Mean Absolute Percentage Error) of 17%. This means that the predictions are within ∓ 17% of the actual values.

To build confidence, we check the results against data that has not been fed into the model, i.e., the 5 days that were isolated and not used to derive the parameters (out-of-sample validation based on a time series split).
On this data-set, we get a MAPE of 14%.
This gives some confidence in building inferences based on this model.
Once the model fit is complete and the predictive capability of the model been assessed, we can see what the parameter inferences are.
If you plot the change in the average R₀ over time, the result is something that you cannot ever fathom. The first time I saw this, it kinda shook me.
The lock-down seems to have worked!
Given that we extracted data from the 2nd of March, this puts the following in perspective:

From the below graph, we can see that most results are bi-modal. This means that there are two points of convergence — the bars in the histograms peak at particular points, specifically two. This could be because of the wide diaspora that lies within the vast Indian subcontinent. Each state has its own position towards the crisis at hand.

This insight leaves me excited to understand, and analyze further, the data for the states in this country. There are multiple applications for analysis of this nature, and I am planning to take one up each week or so. So, stay tuned for those updates!
At the end of this analysis, I am left with mixed feelings. A quote from Arundhati Roy’s recent piece of writing comes to mind.
Who among us is not a quack epidemiologist, virologist, statistician and prophet?

I do want to advocate this analysis. There are enough reasons to do so. A recent study by the Institute of Mathematical Sciences in India concluded that the effects of flattening began showing on the 6th of April. These are in-line with the estimates above.The period of infection and R₀ is within bounds of what has been reported in the Indian media.A prominent economist has also identified with these findings, albeit with a different approach, and this has been presented to the Government of India as of the 24th of April.
Yet, the model has caveats. Nowhere is the system accounting for asymptomatic individuals. Nowhere is the system accounting for incubation periods. We assume a homogeneous population.

Further, India has been criticized for not conducting enough tests. If correct, the implications of not conducting enough tests could mean all projections and insights to be untrue. After all, the model is fit on the data that is available.
As for making decisions based on the output of this model, I’d advice against it. If there’s any inference that can be made, it’s this:
The bi-modal nature of parameters suggests that the contagion is still at large. Please stay home. It’s not safe to venture out.
The lock-down can only work if people don’t go out.
As I write this, the clock has struck 4:00 am. Looking at the numbers, my hopes run high, and I can’t help but feel that we’ll pull through.
I remind myself: we are realists. Neither pessimists, nor optimists.

Note from the editors: Towards Data Science is a Medium publication primarily based on the study of data science and machine learning. We are not health professionals or epidemiologists, and the opinions of this article should not be interpreted as professional advice. To learn more about the coronavirus pandemic, you can click here.
writes jokes. does math. drinks coffee. talks data. builds products.
